history.content:
I don't know how anyone can really "know", but a lot of us have been anticipating it for years now, and frankly I'm surprised it hasn't happened earlier. It's why I've so often urged people (without much success...) to learn to do something in addition to CS, and I tried to do the same myself by taking some circuits classes (though I didn't do so hot in them).

I'm not going to pretend I know anything about economics or history/politics or all that, but I would say be very prepared for a CS (or I guess "tech", since it seems like nothing is worthy of being called "tech" other than CS these days) bubble burst with a nontrivial blast radius to hit you not too long in the future. Neither the supply of money nor the demand for coders is infinite. The way I see it, being computer-savvy is rapidly moving from being an expertise to a matter of basic literacy. Everyone will learn to code sooner or later. in Vietnam they apparently start from 2nd grade and their 11th graders have skills comparable to our college students', and it's only going to get worse (well, better, but worse for you looking for a job).

Personally I would treat coding as a means, not as an end, unless you're actually doing something remotely revolutionary in CS. If half the students graduating from your program have the same skill set as you, you're not exactly going to be distinguishing yourself in an environment where more and more high-schoolers are picking up these skills. So, if you like math, maybe try to learn some statistics; it applies to a wide variety of fields. If you like electronics, give a little more love to Cory Hall, or if moving electrons don't suit your fancy, take some ME/CE/etc. classes... they might give you an edge when you work in a company that requires knowledge outside the "cloud". If you like nature/science, maybe learn a bit of biology; they say it's the science of the 21st century. It doesn't matter. Point is, treat knowing how to code as if it's knowing how to do middle school algebra. It's not like that yet but it may very well become like that not too long in the future.

Just my $0.02... =P

children.subject: Hey, just wondering, why did you choose Public Health? It's not one of the common double majors with CS.

Yeah for sure, I haven't really ever heard of anyone doing a similar combo but can speak to my experience with both.

It first started in high school -- I loved (and continue to love) Biology and applied to Cal as MCB w/ intention of being pre-med. After I got here my interest shifted to doing good in the world at a more macro level and I had also started taking CS classes at that time. I also joined an Epidemiology (how diseases spread in populations) lab that mixed my CS and PH interests together and began doing applied Data Science stuff there which was really cool.

Overall, I really have since Day 1 @ Cal wanted to change the world via my two disciplines and Public Health was something I was really passionate about that has a ton of intersection with CS (via Data Science -- shout out to Data8 and DS100 for being great CS-Public Health intersection classes that have helped me with the work I do for my research lab) so it seemed like a natural path to pursue. 

The plan from here is to do an MPH in Epidemiology and Biostats (hopefully remaining here?) then go work with a health startup/Facebook Data Scientist/CDC Epidemiologist -- idk 100% yet but we'll see.
+1 agree with Mehrdad's answer. Double majoring in Public Health and CS at least partly because of this observation

+1 with above. I'd just like to remind everyone that you are at Berkeley. If all you learn how to do is code while you're here (even if you do it well), that would be a waste. I've noticed a lot of people take the minimum CS/EECS requirement and get out as soon as possible. If you are not in a financially constrained situation take advantage of your extra classes, learn new skills. No one knows what the next big thing will be or what areas of the tech industry will grow into the far future.

history.content: I've heard from some friends that tech companies are starting to lay off more and more staff, and that VCs are giving out less money than before. Is the tech sector starting to slow down? Will there be a similar crash like the Dot Com Bubble of 2000?
history.subject: Is the tech sector starting to slow down?
